docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Bush and Texas Have Not Set High Priority on Health Care'' (front page, April 11): You overlook two important facts. First, Texas has a vast system of free care for the uninsured. Texas spends more than $1,000 per uninsured person every year on free care. That's more than $4,000 for a family of four. This free care is financed through hundreds of programs, many of which are overlapping wasteful and bureaucratic.

headline.main: Bush's Health Plan: Good for Us?

docs.lead_paragraph: BUOYED by an infusion of Internet and telecommunications companies looking for a less-expensive alternative to Manhattan and Fairfield County, Westchester's office market is continuing its rebound from an almost decadelong malaise. ''The numbers this quarter are just unbelievable,'' said Dean J. Shapiro, the executive director of the Insignia/ESG real estate services company in Westchester and Connecticut. ''Last year we really started to see an improvement, and it's just continuing.''

headline.main: In the Region/Westchester; High-Tech Firms Power an Office-Market Rebound

docs.abstract: Westchester County's office market is continuing its rebound from almost decadelong malaise; county's office vacancy rate at end of first quarter of 2000 fell to 13.8 percent, lowest in more than 10 years; robust economy cited, buoyed by infusion of Internet and telecommunications companies looking for less-expensive alternatives to Manhattan and Fairfield County; photo; graphs (In the Region/Westchester) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Edward B. C. Keefer, a surgeon who set up the first transplant bank for human blood vessels and was the first to fit a horse with an artificial leg, died on April 3 at his home in Brookville, N.Y. He was 84. In the 1950's, establishing a forerunner of today's organ banks, Dr. Keefer set up a bank of arteries taken from donors at their time of death for transplant into patients who needed them. He and other doctors had previously devised a procedure to graft arteries.

headline.main: Edward Keefer, a Surgeon, Is Dead at 84

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: An article on March 26 [''Suburban Home Prices: Upward, Ho!''] described 1999 ''as the fourth straight record-setting year for home prices throughout the nation'' Other recent articles note that gasoline prices have been soaring in the last year, health insurance premiums are expected to rise 10 to 15 percent in 2000, and meat, fruit and tobacco prices shot up in February. Such facts and figures, however, don't seem to worry economists and Wall Street professionals who see no signs of inflation. These experts now focus on core inflation, rather than the overall variety, and this core rate, featuring lower auto and computer prices, has been rising at a very modest 0.2 percent per month.
docs.abstract: Letter from Michael Silverstein commenting on Mar 26 article on rising home prices in suburbs; wonders why economists see no signs of inflation

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Bush Is Proposing a Health Plan to Aid the Needy'' (front page, April 12): Gov. George W. Bush would grant a tax credit of $1,000 to an individual to buy private health insurance. But $1,000 is a pitifully small fraction of the $5,000-plus that an individual must pay for even basic insurance.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE sound of a hammer. I hear it when I think of Dance Theater Workshop during the 1960's. For those of us who performed in Jeff Duncan's very small loft on West 20th Street, the hammering was both a ritual and a necessity. Vigorous rehearsing inevitably caused the nails that held the Masonite panels to the scabby old floorboards to work their way upward, a menace to bare feet. Jeff, D.T.W.'s co-founder, did most of the pounding, but, in the spirit of the times, what he and Jack Moore -- a former colleague in Anna Sokolow's company -- spawned 35 years ago was a loose cooperative of dancers and choreographers. ''Where's the hammer?'' Or ''I'll get the hammer,'' we said, and did. Art Bauman, who arrived as a bright young choreographer in 1966, took over an assortment of jobs, like the painstaking stenciling of fliers, and eventually became assistant director. I can remember standing on the bureau in Jeff's partitioned-off sleeping area to run a slide projector for Rudy Perez's ''Topload/Offprint,'' while the Mamas and the Papas wailed from a modest tape deck. One red-letter day, it was decided that everyone rated a fee of $5 per performance.

headline.main: Building a Home For a Fragile, Fiery Community

docs.lead_paragraph: The coalition of hospitals and health care workers that persuaded the Legislature and Gov. George E. Pataki to adopt the most ambitious health care program in recent memory said today that it was ready to pump millions of dollars into an advertising campaign directed at health maintenance organizations. In a now familiar strategy, television and radio ads calling for tougher laws to regulate H.M.O.'s are to go on the air Sunday in the Albany region and spread around the state in coming weeks. The ads have been paid for by the Healthcare Education Project, a coalition of two recently merged unions -- 1199, also known as the National Health and Human Service Employees Union, and the Service Employees International Union -- and the Greater New York Hospital Association.

headline.main: Health Care Coalition Readies Ad Campaign for Tougher Laws on H.M.O.'s

docs.lead_paragraph: In a breakthrough, House and Senate negotiators said today that they had reached a tentative agreement on an appeals process for patients denied care by health maintenance organizations, a major issue in legislation to define patients' rights. Under the agreement, patients could obtain ''an independent medical review'' of any decision in which an H.M.O. denied care or coverage on the ground that a particular service was not medically necessary or was experimental.

headline.main: House and Senate Agree On Patients' Rights Plan

docs.abstract: House and Senate negotiators reach tentative agreement on appeals process for patients denied care by health maintenance organizations, major issue in legislation to define patients' rights; under agreement, patients could obtain independent medical review of any decision in which HMO denied care or coverage on ground that particular service was not medically necessary or was experimental, or if HMO concluded that particular service was not medically necessary or was experimental (M)
